facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 21 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 5 of 1964. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 1, 1961 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in Case Referred No. 21 of 1960.

facts.text: The question referred to the High Court was whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case a sum of Rs. 79,494/- is assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is directed against the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh answering the question referred to it under s. 66 of the Income Tax Act, 1922, against the appellant. The question referred to was whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case a sum of Rs. 79,494/- is assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49.

facts.text: The assessment year in question is 1948-49 and the accounting year is the official year 1947-48.

anchor.surface_text: The facts relevant to the question are as follows. The assessment year in question is 1948-49 and the accounting year is the official year 1947-48.

facts.text: The appellant, Alapati Venkataramaiah, was the proprietor of Mohan Tile Works, engaged in the manufacture of tiles and bricks and owned the factory buildings, plant and machinery.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, hereinafter referred to as the assessee, Alapati Venkataramaiah, was the proprietor of Mohan Tile Works, engaged in the manufacture of tiles and bricks and owned the factory buildings, plant and machinery.

facts.text: The assessee entered into an agreement dated March 17, 1948 with one Shri Manthena Venkata Raju agreeing to sell to the Mohan Industries Limited the factory, plant, machinery, furniture, stocks and goodwill for a sum of Rs. 2,00,000/-

anchor.surface_text: The assessee entered into an agreement dated March 17, 1948. with one Shri Manthena Venkata Raju agreeing to sell to the Mohan Industries Limited, hereinafter called the Company, the aforesaid factory, plant, machinery, furniture, stocks and goodwill for a sum of Rs. 2,00,000/-.

facts.text: The Company was incorporated on July 5, 1947, before the date of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the Company was incorporated on July 5, 1947, before the date of the agreement.

facts.text: The assessee was appointed managing agents of the company on July 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was appointed managing agents of the companypany on July 15, 1947, and on March 11, 1948, he wrote a letter on behalf of the companypany to the Director of Industries and Commerce.

facts.text: On March 11, 1948, the assessee wrote a letter on behalf of the company to the Director of Industries and Commerce, Madras, furnishing a detailed list of land, building and machinery comprising the assets of the company together with their value, in connection with the grant of loan by Government.

anchor.surface_text: and on March 11, 1948, he wrote a letter on behalf of the companypany to the Director of Industries and Commerce. Madras, furnishing a detailed list of land, building and machinery companyprising the assets of the companypany together with their value, in companynection with the grant of loan by Government.

facts.text: On March 20, 1948, the assessee was credited with the price of Rs.200000/- in the books of the company.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1948, the assessee was credited with the price of Rs.200000/- in the books of the companypany.

facts.text: On November 22, 1948, sale deed in respect of land was executed in favour of the company.

anchor.surface_text: On November 22, 1948, sale deed in respect of land was executed in favour of the companypany.

facts.text: On December 9, 1948, the company mortgaged the land with all its buildings and structures thereon and the machinery, plant and other property for Rs. 1,00,000/- to the State of Madras.

anchor.surface_text: On December 9, 1948, the companypany mortgaged the land with all its buildings and structures thereon and the machinery. plant and other property for Rs. 1,00,000/- to the State of Madras.

facts.text: On March 16, 1949, the Board of Directors, by resolution No. 22 approved the agreement dated March 17, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On March 16. 1949. the Board of Directors, by resolution No. 22 approved the agreement dated March 17, 1948, and on April 10, 1949, the agreement was approved at the annual general meeting of the companypany.

facts.text: On April 10, 1949, the agreement was approved at the annual general meeting of the company.

anchor.surface_text: and on April 10, 1949, the agreement was approved at the annual general meeting of the companypany.

facts.text: In the first annual report dated March 22, 1949, it was stated that the company was registered on 5th July 1947 and directors entered into vendors agreement with Sri Alapati Venkatramiah on 17-3-1948.

anchor.surface_text: In the first annual report dated March 22, 1949, it was stated as follows The companypany was registered on 5th July 1947. The Memorandum of Association and Articles alongwith the prospectus of the companypany were published and the shareholders and the public are well aware of the objects and the prospectus of this industry in Andhra. To achieve their objects the directors entered into an agreement called vendors agreement, with Sri Alapati Venkatramiah, Proprietor of Mobart Tile Works on 17-3-1948.

facts.text: The assessee had returned this income as capital gains in his return and the Income Tax Officer held that the assessee realised an excess of Rs.79,494/- over and above the original cost and this was capital gains assessable under s. 12B of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the assessee had returned this income as capital gains in his return and the Income Tax Officer, without any discussion, held that the assessee realised an excess of Rs.79,494/over and above the original companyt and this was capital gains assessable under s. 12B of the Act.

facts.text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who upheld the assessment of Rs. 79,494/- as capital gains.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and in the grounds of appeal stated that the Income Tax Officer erred in determining the excess over the original companyt in respect of the building at Rs. 79,494/- as attracting tax to capital gains. ... I am satisfied that the sum of Rs. 79,494/- as returned by the appellant under the head capital gains was rightly included in the assessment.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal by order dated November 24, 1955 held that there was no sale or legal transfer and deleted the addition.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal. The Tribunal, by its order dated November 24, 1955, held that there was in fact numbersale, much less legal transfer of lands, buil dings, machinery etc., to the limited liability companypany which was promot ed to take over the tiles business. There was only an agreement to sell . ... In the circumstances, we delete the additio n.

facts.text: The Tribunal rectified its order on March 8, 1957 and restored the addition under capital gains.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thereupon came to the companyclusion that its earlier de cision deleting the amount from taxation was based on number-considerati on of various materials on record and it proceeded to rectify this order as a mistake apparent from the record. Accordingly it deleted para 4 i n its order dated November 24, 1955, and substituted its order dated Mar ch 8, 1957.

facts.text: The High Court answered the question in the affirmative against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, it answered the question in the affirmative.

facts.text: The Supreme Court holds that no sale or transfer of immovable assets (machinery Rs. 15,989, electrical fittings Rs. 1,289-10-0, buildings and site Rs. 1,26,470) took place before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is clear that the title to these assets did number pass to the companypany till after April 1, 1948, and companysequently nO sale took place of these assets before April 1, 1948. ... In the result, we hold that the following assets were number sold or transferred before April 1, 1948. Machinery valued at Rs. 15,989-0-0. Electrical fittings valued at Rs. 1,289-10-0. Buildings and site valued at Rs. 1,26,470-0-0.

facts.text: Stocks valued at Rs. 30,050/- are expressly exempt from the definition of capital asset.

anchor.surface_text: Stocks valued at Rs. 30,050/- are expressly exempt from the definition of capital asset, and therefore we hold that numbercapital gain accrued in respect of their sale or transfer.

facts.text: Furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- was transferred before April 1, 1948 by delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that possession of furniture was delivered on March 17, 1948, and as title to furniture can pass by delivery, capital gains, if any, accrued on that date.

facts.text: Goodwill valued at Rs. 7,396/6/- was not transferred before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The position regarding goodwill is however different. It is an intangible asset and it ordinarily passes alongwith the transference of the whole business. It cannot be said in the circumstances of this case that the goodwill was transferred before April 1, 1948.

facts.text: The agreement was approved by the Board of Directors on 26.3.1949 and by general body on 10-4-1949 as per statement of case.

anchor.surface_text: When was the agreement adopted by the companypany? We are relieved from addressing ourselves to this question because in the statement of the case, which was agreed to by the assessee and the Revenue, it is stated that the said agreement was approved and accepted by a resolution of the Board of Directors of the Company on 26.3.1949 and in and by the said resolution the companypany agreed to pay purchase price in instalments companymencing from 31.3.1949. The agreement was subsequently approved by the general body of share holders at a meeting held on 10-4-1949

facts.text: No conveyance was executed before April 1, 1948 for immovable properties.

anchor.surface_text: No such companyveyance was executed before April 1, 1948. It is only on November 22, 1948, that a sale deed was executed and registered in respect of the site.

arguments.claim: No conveyance executed before April 1 1948; title to immovable assets passes only by registered conveyance

anchor.surface_text: No such conveyance was executed before April 1, 1948. It is only on November 22, 1948, that a sale deed was executed and registered in respect of the site. Therefore, it is clear that the title to these assets did not pass to the company till after April 1, 1948

arguments.claim: Transfer under s.12B requires effective conveyance of capital asset; possession alone not sufficient for immovables

anchor.surface_text: Before s. 12B can be attracted, title must pass to the company by any of the modes mentioned in s. 12B, i.e. sale, exchange or transfer. It is true that the word transfer is used in addition to the word sale but even so, in the context transfer must mean effective conveyance of the capital asset to the transferee.

anchor.surface_text: the entries in the account books are irrelevant for the purpose of determining such a date.

arguments.claim: Stocks expressly exempt from capital asset definition; no capital gain

anchor.surface_text: Stocks valued at Rs. 30,050/- are expressly exempt from the definition of capital asset, and therefore we hold that no capital gain accrued in respect of their sale or transfer.

arguments.claim: Title to furniture passed by delivery of possession on March 17 1948 with intention

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that possession of furniture was delivered on March 17, 1948, and as title to furniture can pass by delivery, capital gains, if any, accrued on that date. In the circumstances of the case, delivery must have been made with the intention of passing title.

arguments.claim: Goodwill not transferred before April 1 1948; intangible passes with whole business

anchor.surface_text: The position regarding goodwill is however different. It is an intangible asset and it ordinarily passes alongwith the transference of the whole business. It cannot be said in the circumstances of this case that the goodwill was transferred before April 1, 1948.

holdings.text: It seems to us that it was a conditional agreement to sell and before it could ripen into a contract between the company and the assessee, it had to be adopted by the company.

anchor.surface_text: Further it is contended that it is a conditional agreement to sell. Reliance is placed on clauses 8 and 9 of the agreement. Clause 8 expressly contemplates adoption of the agreement by the company in such manner as to render the same binding on the company, and clause 9 contemplates that it is only after the adoption

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clauses 8 and 9 expressly require adoption by company to bind it; appropriate for agent-principal; cannot rewrite agreement.

holdings.text: the said agreement was approved and accepted by a resolution of the Board of Directors of the Company on 26.3.1949 ... The agreement was subsequently approved by the general body of share holders at a meeting held on 10-4-1949 and on such approval, acceptance and adoption, the agreement became binding on the assessee and the company.

anchor.surface_text: When was the agreement adopted by the company? We are relieved from addressing ourselves to this question because in the statement of the case, which was agreed to by the assessee and the Revenue, it is stated that the said agreement was approved and accepted by a resolution of the Board of Directors of the Company on 26.3.1949 and in and by the said resolution the company agreed to pay purchase price in instalments commencing from 31.3.1949. The agreement was subsequently approved by the general body of share holders at a meeting held on 10-4-1949

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per agreed statement of case, adoption occurred in 1949, making agreement binding then.

holdings.text: No such conveyance was executed before April 1, 1948. It is only on November 22, 1948, that a sale deed was executed and registered in respect of the site. Therefore, it is clear that the title to these assets did not pass to the company till after April 1, 1948, and consequently no sale took place of these assets before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: No such conveyance was executed before April 1, 1948. It is only on November 22, 1948, that a sale deed was executed and registered in respect of the site. Therefore, it is clear that the title to these assets did not pass to the company till after April 1, 1948, and consequently nO sale took place of these assets before April 1, 1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Title to immovable property passes only by registered conveyance; cites CIT v Bhurangya Coal Co.

holdings.text: In the result, we hold that the following assets were not sold or transferred before April 1, 1948. Machinery valued at Rs. 15,989-0-0. Electrical fittings valued at Rs. 1,289-10-0. Buildings and site valued at Rs. 1,26,470-0-0.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is clear that the title to these assets did number pass to the companypany till after April 1, 1948, and companysequently nO sale took place of these assets before April 1, 1948. ... In the result, we hold that the following assets were number sold or transferred before April 1, 1948. Machinery valued at Rs. 15,989-0-0. Electrical fittings valued at Rs. 1,289-10-0. Buildings and site valued at Rs. 1,26,470-0-0.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No conveyance before 1.4.1948; immovable assets include embedded machinery and fittings.

holdings.text: the entries in the account books are irrelevant for the purpose of determining such a date.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has relied on the entries made in the account books of the assessee and the company on March 20, 1948, but the date of sale or transfer according to s. 12B is the date when the sale or transfer takes place, and it seems to us that the entries in the account books are irrelevant for the purpose of determining such a date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Date of sale/transfer under s.12B determined by legal transfer, not accounting entries.

holdings.text: Delivery of possession of immovable property cannot by itself be treated as equivalent to conveyance of the immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: Before s. 12B can be attracted, title must pass to the company by any of the modes mentioned in s. 12B, i.e. sale, exchange or transfer. ... Delivery of possession of immovable property cannot by itself be treated as equivalent to conveyance of the immovable property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfer under s.12B requires effective conveyance of title; s.53A part performance does not suffice for capital gains.

holdings.text: Stocks valued at Rs. 30,050/- are expressly exempt from the definition of capital asset, and therefore we hold that no capital gain accrued in respect of their sale or transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Stocks valued at Rs. 30,050/- are expressly exempt from the definition of capital asset, and therefore we hold that numbercapital gain accrued in respect of their sale or transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of definition excluding stock-in-trade.

holdings.text: There is no doubt that possession of furniture was delivered on March 17, 1948, and as title to furniture can pass by delivery, capital gains, if any, accrued on that date. In the circumstances of the case, delivery must have been made with the intention of passing title.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdoubt that possession of furniture was delivered on March 17, 1948, and as title to furniture can pass by delivery, capital gains, if any, accrued on that date. In the circumstances of the case, delivery must have been made with the intention of passing title.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Title to movables passes by delivery of possession with intent.

holdings.text: The position regarding goodwill is however different. It is an intangible asset and it ordinarily passes alongwith the transference of the whole business. It cannot be said in the circumstances of this case that the goodwill was transferred before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The position regarding goodwill is however different. It is an intangible asset and it ordinarily passes alongwith the transference of the whole business. It cannot be said in the circumstances of this case that the goodwill was transferred before April 1, 1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goodwill passes with whole business transfer; no evidence of separate transfer before 1.4.1948.

holdings.text: Accordingly, we hold that only one asset, namely, furniture was transferred before April 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that only one asset, namely, furniture was transferred before April 1, 1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesis of above determinations on each asset.

holdings.text: In the result, we answer the question referred to the High Court as follows In the facts and circumstances of the case the sum of Rs. 79,494/- is not assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49, but only such part of it, if any, as is attributable to the capital gain made by the transfer of furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- is assessable.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, we hold that only one asset, namely, furniture was transferred before April 1, 1948. In the result, we answer the question referred to the High Court as follows In the facts and circumstances of the case the sum of Rs. 79,494/- is number assessable as capital gains in the assessment year 1948-49, but only such part of it, if any, as is attributable to the capital gain made by the transfer of furniture valued at Rs. 18,805/- is assessable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only furniture transfer qualifies under s.12B for 1948-49; others do not.
